intro: Chamaesyce carmenensis, commonly known as Carmen's sandmat, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Portulacaceae, which includes many species adapted to dry environments. The plant is a low-growing perennial with fleshy, succulent leaves that help it retain moisture in its harsh habitat. Its small, pinkish-white flowers bloom in the spring, adding a delicate touch to its otherwise sparse appearance. The species is notable for its ability to thrive in sandy soils and its resilience to drought conditions.
